user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CountSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CountSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);

    if (sem_post(&impl->id) < 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_CountSemGive_Impl:
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t OS_impl_count_sem_table[OS_MAX_COUNT_SEMAPHORES]
...
typedef struct
{
    sem_t id;
} OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_count_sem_table, *token);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: Not violated. The function parameter is declared const OS_object_token_t *token and OS_ObjectIndexFromToken expects a const OS_object_token_t *, so passing *token into the macro (which takes &(*token)) preserves the const qualification. The retrieved table element is a non-const OS_impl_countsem_internal_record_t (the global table is non-const) and impl must be non-const because sem_post(&impl->id) modifies the semaphore. Thus no opportunity to make the pointer point to a const-qualified type without preventing required modifications. (A violation would occur if a pointer to an object that is not modified were declared non-const when it could be const—for example, if impl were only used for read-only access but not const-qualified.)
